snippet: Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government and to compete for influence with each other and with their Islamist rivals.
abstract: Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates pledge $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up its shaky transitional government and to compete for influence with each other and their Islamist rivals; gulf intervention contrasts sharply with Obama administration's uncertainty about how to respond to Egypt's military takeover and, more broadly, how to wield influence across increasingly chaotic and fragmented Arab world.
lead_paragraph: Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government and to compete for influence with each other and with their Islamist rivals.

headline.main: Egypt Is Arena for Influence of Arab Rivals
headline.print_headline: Egypt Is Arena For Influence Of Arab Rivals
